Vajrasena, Vajrasena
The monk Vajrasena was a person from the Western Regions. He lived at Qingyuan Gorge Mountain Temple. He was able to
chant in Sanskrit, flick his tongue, shake his staff, and cast spells on things.
There was nothing that did not respond.
He was good at capturing ghosts and spirits, and binding mosquitoes and scorpions.
With a single sound of his staff,
he could summon thunder to strike immediately.
On that day, there was a Li Pu at Gorge Mountain Temple.
He held an axe and cut down a huge tree.
He hollowed it out to make a boat.
Suddenly, he climbed the mountain and saw a cave on a flat rock.
He saw a giant spider with legs spanning over a zhang wide.
Four snakes bit the grass to block the cave and left.
Suddenly, he heard a violent roar from the trees.
The workers were afraid and climbed the trees to watch.
Sure enough, they saw a giant snake several tens of zhang long.
It coiled and writhed in anger, surrounding the spider's cave.
Its heads were in the east and west.
Suddenly, the western head sucked the grass from the cave.
And flew out, escaping completely.
Later, it turned east, opened its eyes wide, and opened its mouth wide.
It sucked the spider, and the spider ran out.
It caught the spider with its feet and put it in its mouth.
It raised and bent its poison.
It was as red as fire.
It burned the viper's throat and removed the viper's eyes.
The viper was dazed and revived.
It raised its head and sucked again.
The spider was not seen again, and the viper was poisoned.
The viper finally fell on a rock and died.
The spider jumped out and chewed on the viper's abdomen.
Its inner teeth broke and two heads came out, spinning silk and bagging it.
It jumped out of the hole and left.
Park was amazed and returned to Gyaksan Temple to tell Kim Gang-seon.
The monk then asked Park to test the hole, shook his ringed staff, and chanted.
The spider then came out in front of the monk, as if listening to the spirits.
When the monk touched it with his staff,

That night, the monk dreamed of an old man holding a piece of silk and coming forward, saying:
I am the spider.
I can also weave.
He bowed to the monks and said,
I wish to be a support for the field of blessings.
After speaking, he died.
The monks and Jubu were by his side.
The craftsmanship and ingenuity were not something that ordinary silkworms could produce.
The monks then made it into a robe.
Dust and dirt did not stick to it.
After several years, the monk wanted to go to Panyu and sail to India.
He shook his staff and shouted loudly, cursing the water by the Golden Lock Pool in Jiashan.
Suddenly the water parted and the bottom was seen.
He used a washbasin to scoop it up.
There was a mud eel, about three inches long.
It jumped into the basin.
He told the monks,
This is a dragon.
I will go to the sea gate and cook it with medicine to make an ointment to apply to my feet, so that crossing the sea will be like walking on level ground.
